handDesc.p: Halantas. In the Telugu section, there occurs a final form of Ḷ. Instances are found from line 23 onward. It looks like a full-sized ḷa without a headmark, though it can be simplified to a wavy vertical line with a loop at the bottom, as in l28, -konthukaḶ. Final N (l16, pramukhāN) is simplified, with a long stem and no headmark.

Other palaeographic observations. As Fleet obseres, in l10 °opajāyamāno°, jā is formed very strangely, with a downward-bending vowel marker attached to the top prong of j. In l15 -jvālā, the vowel is also attached to the upper prong, but it bends upward. The weird khā in line 16, which Fleet calls "very anomalous", looks essentially like a pa, with the right limb bending outward. It has some resemblance to a khā that, according to Indoskript, occurs in the Vijayawada plates of Cālukya-Bhīma I. Short and long i/ī are not distinguished in the Telugu section (except in some words perceived to be Sanskrit, e.g. l24 śrīya). Though Fleet reads some (incorrect) long ī-s there when the circle is not completely closed on the left, in my opinion these are just less well executed short i-s. They definitely lack the conspicuous inward hook of instances of long ī in the Sanskrit. In the Telugu part, anusvāras are placed at the top right of the character after the character to which they belong (and were thus read by Fleet as being one character further on than they were meant to be).

app.note: An initially engraved tū may have been corrected partially to stū.

The last three characters in line 2 (especially pali) are horizontally compressed and squeezed together. There is no trace of correction, but it seems quite certain to me that at first, pālitānāṁ must have been engraved, after which li was struck out and ripali was added in its place.

The character duā, with two vowel markers, may be a scribal mistake for a pre-written ddhā, itself a mistake for dhyā. The subscript component of the next character, which I read with JFF as th, is a rough circle divided into four quarters by a cross. It is conspicuously different from the standalone th in the Sanskrit section (line 5, °āvabhr̥tha) as well as from subscript th-s (line 9, cakravatthi; l13, atthi). It is, however, also not a proper ṟ, and looks identical to several characters that JFF reads as th in the Telugu section.
The two characters marked as superfluous (eyeskip dittography) may have been in fact struck out in the original.
I accept JFF's reading, but ḷu in fact looks like ḍu or du.

I adopt JFF's emendations, but śīghra-pavanaḥ on its own strikes me as very odd and I suspect corruption. Perhaps a longer burst of eulogy was omitted here, compare para-gaja-ghana-paṭala-pavanaḥ in line 9 of the Lohaner plates of Pulakeśin II. Or perhaps he is a wind to enemy kings (e.g. -nr̥peṣūgra-pavanaḥ) who have already been touched by the flame of his valour, i.e. he hastens their destruction?
JFF's vā is probably a tentative emendation, while his kiṁ is an uncertain alternative reading. It is clear from the Elliot estampages that no anusvāra is present.
Probably a typo in KMS.

JFF prints a clear ḍ, while KMS's d may be a typo or an error of my scan. The character is not a definite ḍ as it lacks a notch in its bottom, but it is also not a d, as the end of its body stroke curves upward and inward.
According to KMS's note, this may be for 'icciri'.

The last character of line 22 is partly invisible in Elliot's rubbing because the paper did not fit the rim of the plate well, but it is quite clear in Fleet's estampage. It is indeed more likely to be ce than ve.

The problematic character's subscript component is quite certainly l. The principal component is a circle with a horizontal line crossing it; a similar character occurs in line 3 and several times in the following lines. It may have been meant for th or ḻ, but it differs from clear instances of either. Not understanding the language, I do not know if KMS's reading is meaningful. I suspect his d may be either a silent normalisation of th, or a typo (or a scanning problem) for ḍ (itself being a silent normalisation of an original ḻ).
The intent was probably -bhuvanvśrīya; compare savva-lokaśraya in line 26.

The first character definitely looks like ma; I believe Fleet read sa on the assumption that this is a Sanskrit word. The second character (which was obviously added afterward in the space between the first and the third) is, however, quite certainly ka; KMS's reading may be a silent emendation.
See the note to line 23 about the problematic character. This instance is a circle with a cross inside.
The intent was probably as emended by JFF. However, compare bhuvana-śrīya in line 24.
The problematic character is probably the same as that described in the note to line 23, but this instance is a circle with nothing inside.
The problematic character is the same as that described in the note to line 23, this time appearing like a circle with a T shape inside.
The problematic character is the same as that described in the note to line 23, again appearing like a circle with a T shape inside.

I accept KMS's reading, which he prints as clear. The problematic character is undamaged, but strangely formed because it is squeezed in below the large descender of ṣṇu in the previous line, while apparently trying not to descend too far below into the space for the last line on the plate. Still, it is more likely to be a single character than two extremely constricted ones.
The problematic character is the same as that described in the note to line 23, this time as a circle or oval with nothing inside.
The problematic character is distinctly different from the following ma, so I prefer to assume it is a correct va with an accidental extra stroke.
The problematic character is the same as that described in the note to line 23, this time as a circle with two lines inside, pointing to 12 and 3 o'clock from the centre.
Since Fleet does not emend, his ā is probably a typo.

div.p: Greetings. The grandson of His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana III or IV, who made the complete circle of the earth bow down by the power of the blade of his sword and who was eager to adorn the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra which is praised by the entire world, who are sons of Hāriti, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by Lord Mahāsena, to whom the realms of adversaries instantaneously submit at the mere sight of the superior Boar emblem they have acquired by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose bodies have been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice—; the dear son of His Majesty King mahārāja Vijayāditya, the eradicatorI translate kāriṇaḥ as derived from the root kr̥̄, but I suspect that the text is corrupt and the word is in fact a fragment of a longer compound ending with kāriṇaḥ derived from kr̥. who by a mere frown dispersed all enemy kingdoms, whose body was cleansed by the distribution of gold weighed on many balance scales, That is, gold weighed on a scale against his body, the tulāpuruṣa mahādāna. His Majesty the supremely pious King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana IV or V, shelter of all the world sarva-lokāśraya, supreme devotee of Maheśvara, who possesses the bodily marks of a universal sovereign cakravartin, who is the beloved of Royal Fortune lakṣmī as Viṣṇu the Bearer of the Discus is the beloved of Lakṣmī, whose success is as evident as the rising of the sun, who produces delight in the world like the moon with its rays, who scatters gifts like a divine elephant sprinkling rut fluid, who is profound by nature, like the ocean, who is attended by a fearsome army like Yudhiṣṭhira who is attended by Bhīmasena, whose power is as irresistible as the spear of Kārttikeya, who is equipped with the three powers śakti-traya, learned in the four royal sciences, capable of hard-won victory viṣama-siddhi in battles, a cow of plenty kāmadhenu to supplicants, a crocodile-bannered god of love to women, a doomsday sun to dispel the darkness of his enemies, the flames of the wildfire of whose blazing valour have licked enemy kings, a swift wind, There is probably something wrong with the text here. I translate as best I can, but see the apparatus note to line 15., a conqueror vijigīṣu who conquers righteously dharma-vijayin—this Viṣṇuvardhana commands all householders kuṭumbin—including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa— as follows: let it be known to you that we have given The text leaves off abruptly here, and the Telugu section (@@@not translated here) begins anew with the salutation svasti.

Prospérité ! Le petit-fils de l’illustre grand roi Viṣṇuvardhana, qui a conquis le cercle de la terre immense par la puissance de la lame de son épée, ornement de la lignée des Calukya, illustres, du même gotra que les descendants de Manu, honorés dans le monde entier, fils de Hāriti, qui obtinrent leur royaume grâce à la l’excellente faveur de Kauśikī, protégés par la troupe des Mères, méditant aux pieds du seigneur Mahāsena, dont les cercles ennemis furent soumis en un instant à la vue du signe du sanglier illustre, faveur octroyée par le bienheureux Nārāyaṇa, dont les corps furent purifiés par les bains purificatoires de l’aśvamedha, le cher fils de l’illustre grand roi Vijayāditya, destructeur qui a balayé le cercle de tous ses ennemis par son seul froncement de sourcil, qui a purifié son corps en pesant maintes donations d’or,Allusion au sacrifice dit tulābhāra au cours duquel le roi donne son poids en or à un ou à plusieurs brahmanes. lui qui porte la marque d’un souverain cakravartin ; bien-aimé de la Fortune, comme Cakradhara est le bien-aimé de Lakṣmī, il voit s’accroître sa prospérité comme le soleil levant, il fait le bonheur de l’univers comme la lune le réjouit de ses rayons, il fait pleuvoir des dons, comme l’éléphant des dieux fait pleuvoirs le dāna, il possède un profond courage, comme l’océan dont la profondeur est la nature, il dispose d’une armée terrifiante, comme Yudhiṣṭhira est accompagné de Bhīmasena, sa puissance est invaincue comme la lance de Kārtikeya, dont les pouvoirs sont inattaquables, il est doué des trois pouvoirs, expert dans les quatre sciences des rois,La philosophie, les trois Veda, l’économie et les traités politiques. Arthaśāstra, 1, 2, 1. il obtient des succès difficiles dans les combats, il est la vache des désirs pour les miséreux, Makaradhvaja pour les femmes, s’agissant de disperser ces ténèbres que sont les ennemis, il est le soleil de la Grande Destruction, feu impétueux dont les flammes du brasier qu’est son énergie flamboyante lèchent les rois ennemis, vijigīṣu, conquérant du dharma, très pieux, excellent seigneur, le grand roi illustre, refuge de tous les hommes, Viṣṇuvardhana, ordonne ceci à tous chefs de familles, rāṣṭrakūṭa en tête : qu’il soit connu de vous que par nous à Pr̥thivi-pallava-paṭṭana ?La suite du texte semble être rédigée en telugu, nous n’avons pu proposer une traduction.

The plates had a ring, which was cut by the time Fleet saw it. The seal was also lost by that time. Or perhaps a seal was never attached, as the authenticity of the plates is questionable. The Telugu section may be in a different hand (compare especially the shape of ta in the two sections: in the Sanskrit it is the form found in earlier Cālukya plates, while in the Telugu it looks almost like the modern Telugu glyph). But I think it is more likely that it is the same hand, and probably a late one, who attempted to imitate an earlier style throughout the document, and to a greater extent in the Sanskrit section. @@@In the Telugu section of the grant, I follow Fleet's readings and adopt his emendations unless otherwise indicated in the apparatus. Thus, in that section all editorial intervention encoded as a correction (including addition and suppression) follows Fleet's emendations, and all intervention encoded as a normalisation follows Fleet's tentative suggestions. In various spots, my scans of the plates are unclear, particularly on page 3r. It seems that in Fleet's notation, (?abc) means that "abc" may be the correct reading instead of that indicated before the parentheses, while (abc?) means a tentative emendation. I encode the former as unclear with @cert="low" or as a choice of two unclear items, as applicable.
